values: Randy Pausch died today. I am watching this tonight.

I predict that we'll see the following costumes at Dragon*Con 2008:

Dr. Horrible
(From Doctor Who) Naked Gooey Clone Martha Jones
"Dark Knight" movie Joker
Iron Man (though this is cheating-I know someone who's building the armor)

Maybe we won't see Naked Gooey Clone Martha.  But dammit, we should!  I feel the con is clamoring for this.

Oh heck.

I just got an announcement via Facebook telling me that there will be no Whose Line Improv competition at Dragon*Con this year.

That has consistently been one of my favorite parts of the con, and it will be missed.

Goodbye, George.

That was a strong opening.
<lj-cut text="Spoilers Under the Cut">
The opening battle was great.

Baltar really does seem to embrace whatever new role he gets thrust into, doesn't he?  And the Six in Baltar's head is wearing a proper outfit now.

Lee looks to be going into the government.  I look forward to seeing where that goes.

My idea that Starbuck would be inside Lee's head has turned out to be wrong.  No clear answer on whether or not she's a cylon.  It's certainly a nice update to the "angel" stuff from the original series.

The four secret cylons seem pretty bewildered at present.  I'm wondering where that's going.

The previews for next week seem to be showing some sort of cylon conflict.

That was fun.
</lj-cut>

William F. Buckley passed away today. Last year, I found this article on a National Review sponsored cruise ship fascinating, and a little sad. Buckley's opposition to the Iraq War made him deeply unpopular. Link (via Wikipedia)

I found out recently that there's a group that somehow keeps track of descendants of Confucius. The organization has been around since 1930, and there are two million people they've certified as descendants. They estimate that there are as many as three million descendants. Confucius was born in 551 BC and died in 479 BC. How on Earth are they substantiating this? According to wikipedia, the Chinese have been keeping track of (and often honoring) his descendants continually until around 1935. Imagine if somebody in the West could say the same thing. "Yeah, I'm descended from Socrates." "Really? I'm descended from Alexander the Great." It does present an interesting question. If you could pick a historical figure you could legitimately claim descent from, who would that be? Personally, I'd pick Benjamin Franklin. He is far and away my favorite Founding Father. Link (Via Rawstory)

Comic book writer Steve Gerber passed away (due to pulmonary fibrosis). He co-created Howard the Duck, and his credits include the Defenders, Omega the Unknown, and Foolkiller. He also wrote for several cartoons in the 80's (such as GI Joe and Dungeons & Dragons), and created Thundarr the Barbarian (the cartoon, not the character). Link (Mark Evanier's Blog) Link (Steve Gerber)
Mitt Romney's hair. Link (Crooks & Liars) Link (Crooks & Liars/Daily Show Coverage)

I was checking out wikipedia, and it looks like the third installment in James Ellroy's American Underworld trilogy will be out this summer. It'll be called Blood's a Rover, and it will cover the years 1968 to 1973.

I have a dear friend named Sarah who is a Pastafarian. Sarah is hosting a potluck dinner/movie night tomorrow evening, and I thought I'd bring something special. I found instructions the other day on how to make Flying Spaghetti Monster cookies, and I'm trying it out. You can find the instructions here (via Boing Boing). The materials I used were premade sugar cookie dough, a garlic press, and a knife. I used the garlic press to make the noodly appendages, and I formed the eyestalks by hand. I intend to use some red icing for the eyes after the batch is done. Here's the "Before" Picture. I'll update this blog entry after the batch is finished. UPDATE: Here's what the first batch looks like now that they're done. I added red icing for the eyes, as you can see. Here's a close up of one of the cookies. This was a fun experiment.

I had a nice New Year's Eve.

Charles RB called me at around 8:30 pm or so to wish me a Happy New Year.  I had a choice between dancing at one party and hanging out at another, and I found myself more in the mood for conversation.  Had a nice time with <lj user=kinesys> and some people I hadn't seen in years.  Also met and had some really nice conversations with some people from among kinesys' LARPer friends.

I was up till about 4.  I didn't drink, and I promised someone I would drive him home.  Unfortunately, the card game he was in took a lot longer than I anticipated.  Then he found another ride.  Ah well.  I had fun, and I figure it's good karma.

I hope everyone had a fun New Year's Eve, and I hope you all have a great 2008.

It's been going around the net recently that Vladimir Putin has accumulated a fortune valued at $40 billion. I think the Guardian first covered it, and the story can be found here. So I've been wondering what I'd do with $40 billion. More importantly I've been asking all my friends what they'd do with $40 billion. Now I'm asking you. What would you do with $40 billion? So post your answers here, and feel free to get everybody on your friends list to answer the same question. Spike-X said that he'd give money to his kids and the mother of his child. Also, he'd spend money on healthcare for the aborigines in Australia. Cosmic Cat said she'd travel. Mike Smash said he'd set up his own political party and work to bring single payer universal healthcare to the United States. Stony says he'd work to build up New Zealand in the domain of science and technology. Not sure what steps he'd take, but $40 billion would certainly give him options. Personally, I would build a space elevator (I'd probably buy Liftport to do it). I'd set up a working space elevator, and use that to seed orbit with solar power collecting satellites. I'd use those satellites to beam cheap energy to the surface. I'd make a mint, and it would be of tremendous benefit to society. There would be other projects. I'd work to use the space elevator to dispose of nuclear waste by taking it up into orbit and launching it towards the Sun. I'd work on building low-G manufacturing stations. Orbital tourism. That sorta thing. And I'd name my space elevator the Beanstalk.

My friend Stony just asked me who I'd cast as a female version of the Doctor if the powers that be decided to go that way. Off the top of my head, I think Indira Varma would be a fun choice. I loved her as Niobe on HBO's Rome.

It took 12 years to do it (and $2.7 billion), but the horse genome has been mapped. It's only a start, of course. There's still more to learn and all. But it's certainly a milestone. Science is awesome. Link

Here are three of my favorite quotes:

"I don't think there's a single problem facing this planet that can't be solved. I think some of them, the solutions, already exist. The problem is implementing the solutions."
Robert Anton Wilson

"We're the species that goes beyond our limitations, and so expanding our horizons with our tools is really what human civilization is all about."
Ray Kurzweil

"And I think this is a great example of the fact that life rewards people who move in the direction of greatest courage."
<lj user=tacit>

Honestly, I should include a more complete version of the Robert Anton Wilson quote, too:

"I don't think there's a single problem facing this planet that can't be solved. I think some of them, the solutions, already exist. The problem is implementing the solutions.  Getting the power elite to recognize that this is in their own best interest, too.  To allow some changes to occur."
Robert Anton Wilson
